newsitem.title: BELGIUM: Brussels bourse volume seen rising from Monday.
newsitem.headline: Brussels bourse volume seen rising from Monday.

text.p: Belgian shares rose on Friday, helped by gains in early Wall Street trade, but dealers said most people making investment decisions were still on holiday.
"Many investors are on holiday today, the market is recovering mainly due to Wall Street," said one trader.
Another trader said "the real beginning of the year will be on Monday (January 6)".
The blue-chip Bel-20 index closed up 1.01 percent, or 18.84 points, to 1,889.89 but with only a modest 1.43 billion francs volume of shares traded.

Dealers said attention would focus on cyclical stocks in coming months as support from the bond market, which helped interest-rate sensitive equities in 1996, was not likely to be as strong this year.
"Many investors are looking for industrial stocks because they're betting that the economy will improve this year," said one trader.
Chemicals firm Tessenderlo rallied to close up 7.0 percent to 14,500 francs.
"There is a big buyer on the market today, probably an institutional investor," said one trader.
"It (Tessenderlo) is not a cheap stock now but the stories that have come out recently, like it will expand into France, have made investors want to buy the share," said one trader.
But trader Benoit Kint at brokerage Petercam said "it's too high a price (at 14,500 francs) to pay at the moment, especially as nobody knows the PVC prices for 1997".
Elsewhere cement maker CBR climbed 4.2 percent to 2,960 francs with dealers putting it down to expectations that the European market will recovery in 1997.
Its recent increased stake in China Century Cement Ltd (CCC), to 30 percent from a previous five percent, has also encouraged investors to buy the stock.
Dollar-sensitive retailer Delhaize saw the biggest volume of shares traded on the Bel-20, closing up 2.2 percent to 1,890 francs.
"Food Lion's fourth-quarter report just published showed turnover in line with market expectations, this puts Delhaize (Food Lion's parent company) in a good position for 1997," said one trader.

Delhaize is due to release 1996 sales and provisional earnings figures next week. Brokerage G-Securities forecast sales up 12.5 percent to 415 billion Belgian francs and earnings per share up 19 percent to 87 francs.
